introduction.p:
Let's consider the initial value problem
\frac{dy}{dt} = t - 2, \ \ y(0) = 1 .

statement.p: Use the differential equation to find the slope of the tangent line to the solution y(t) at t=0. Then use the initial value to find the equation of the tangent line at t=0. Sketch this tangent line over the interval -0.25 \leq t \leq 0.25 on the axes provided in Figure.

Also shown in Figure are the tangent lines to the solution y(t) at the points t=1, 2, and 3 (we will see how to find these later). Use the graph to measure the slope of each tangent line and verify that each agrees with the value specified by the differential equation.
Using these tangent lines as a guide, sketch a graph of the solution y(t) over the interval 0\leq t\leq 3 so that the lines are tangent to the graph of y(t).
Use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to find y(t), the solution to this initial value problem.
Graph the solution you found in (d) on the axes provided, and compare it to the sketch you made using the tangent lines.
